message_1: A manufacturer wants to test the quality of a new clothing fabric. They take a sample of 50 pieces of the fabric from the production line and measure the thickness of each piece in millimeters. The sample has a mean thickness of 2.9mm and a standard deviation of 0.4mm. What is the 95% confidence interval for the true mean thickness of the fabric?
message_2:
To calculate the 95% confidence interval for the true mean thickness of the fabric, we will use the following formula:

Confidence Interval = Mean ± (Z-score * (Standard Deviation / √Sample Size))

For a 95% confidence interval, the Z-score is 1.96 (from the standard normal distribution table).

Given:
Mean (x̄) = 2.9 mm
Standard Deviation (σ) = 0.4 mm
Sample Size (n) = 50

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

Confidence Interval = 2.9 ± (1.96 * (0.4 / √50))

Confidence Interval = 2.9 ± (1.96 * (0.4 / 7.071))

Confidence Interval = 2.9 ± (1.96 * 0.0566)

Confidence Interval = 2.9 ± 0.111

Lower Limit = 2.9 - 0.111 = 2.789 mm
Upper Limit = 2.9 + 0.111 = 3.011 mm

So, the 95% confidence interval for the true mean thickness of the fabric is (2.789 mm, 3.011 mm).
